## The Standard Model

::: {class="fragment" style="font-size:1.4em; font-weight:300; margin-top:40px;"}
The most successful theory of **fundamental interactions** (so far)
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="font-size:1.1em; margin-top:30px;"}
**Gauge principle:** <br>
Interactions arise by requiring invariance under local symmetry transformations.
:::

:::{.r-hstack style="align-items: center; justify-content:flex-start; gap:180px;"}

::: {class="fragment" style="font-size:1.1em; margin-top:10px; text-align:left"}
- **Electromagnetic** → $\mathrm{U}(1)_{\text{em}}$ <br> <span style="font-size:0.8em; color:gray;">acts on charged particles </span>
- **Weak** → $\mathrm{SU}(2)_L$ <br><span style="font-size:0.8em; color:gray;"> responsable of radioactive decays </span>
- **Strong** →  $\mathrm{SU}(3)_C$<br><span style="font-size:0.8em; color:gray;">binds quarks inside hadrons </span>  

:::

::: {class="fragment" style="font-size:1.1em; margin-top:10px; text-align: center"}
$$\mathcal{L}_{\text{SM}} \;=\; \mathcal{L}_{\text{gauge}} + \mathcal{L}_{\text{matter}} + \mathcal{L}_{\text{Higgs}}$$
:::
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="font-size:1.1em; font-style:italic; color:gray; margin-top:40px; margin-right:70px; text-align: right; "}
Gravity unfortunately is not included in the Standard Model.
:::

## QCD in the Continuum 

<div data-id="lag" style="margin-top:-30px;">
$$\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{QCD}} =-\tfrac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}\left[ F_{\mu\nu} F^{\mu\nu}\right]+\sum_{f=1}^{N_f} \bar{\psi}_f \big( i \gamma^\mu D_\mu - m_f \big) \psi_f$$
</div>

## QCD in the Continuum {auto-animate=true auto-animate-easing="ease-in-ease-out" auto-animate-duration=1}

<div data-id="lag" style="margin-top:-30px;">
$$\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{QCD}} =\textcolor{#EB811B}{-\tfrac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}\left[F_{\mu\nu} F^{\mu\nu}\right]}
+\sum_{f=1}^{N_f} \bar{\psi}_f \big( i \gamma^\mu D_\mu - m_f \big)\psi_f$$
</div>

:::: {.columns }

::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"}
::: {class="fragment"}
- **Gauge fields**:
<div style="margin-top:-20px;">
  $$\normalsize A_\mu(x) = \sum_{a=1}^8 A_\mu^a(x)\, T^a$$
</div>
  - $\small \left[ T_a,T_b\right]= i f_{abc}T_c$ and $\small \left\{ T_a,T_b\right\}= \frac 1 2 \delta_{ab}$
  - $\small A_\mu(x)$ encapsulates the 8 gluons 
  - $\small A_\mu^a(x)\in \mathfrak{su}(3)$.

:::

::: {class="fragment"}

- **Field strength tensor**: 

<div style="margin-top:-20px;">
$$
  F_{\mu\nu} = \partial_\mu A_\nu - \partial_\nu A_\mu
  - i g \,[A_\mu, A_\nu]
$$
</div>

:::

:::

::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"}

::: {class="fragment"}
- **Gauge transformations**:  
    $\small \forall\; U(x) \in \mathrm{SU}(3)$
<div style="margin-top:-10px; margin-left:80px;">
$$
 \begin{array}{rcl}
    A_\mu & \longrightarrow & UA_\mu U^\dagger \\
    F_{\mu\nu} & \longrightarrow & U\,F_{\mu\nu}\,U^\dagger 
  \end{array}
$$
</div>

:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-27px"}
- **Covariance**:  
  - $\small F_{\mu\nu}$ transforms *homogeneously*  
  - $\small \mathrm{Tr}[F_{\mu\nu}F^{\mu\nu}]$ is **gauge invariant**
:::

:::

::::

::: {class="fragment" style="font-size:1.0em; font-style:italic; color:gray; margin-top:-20px; margin-right:0px; text-align:right;"}
**[Pure gauge]{style="color: #EB811B;"} → already highly non-trivial:**  
confinement, glueballs, non-linear self-interactions...
:::


## QCD in the Continuum 

<div data-id="lag" style="margin-top:-30px;">
$$\mathcal{L}_{\mathrm{QCD}} =
-\tfrac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}\left[F_{\mu\nu} F^{\mu\nu}\right]
+\textcolor{#EB811B}{\sum_{f=1}^{N_f} \bar{\psi}_f \big( i \gamma^\mu D_\mu - m_f \big)\psi_f}$$
</div>

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"}

::: {class="fragment"}
- **Quark fields**:  
  - $\small \psi_f(x)$ &rightarrow; flavor $\small f=1,\dots,N_f$
  - Real world &rightarrow; $\small N_f = 6$
  - Fundamental rep. of $\small \mathrm{SU}(3)_C$
    - $\small \psi_f(x)$ &rightarrow; $\small (\textcolor{red}{\psi_f(x)}, \textcolor{green}{\psi_f(x)}, \textcolor{blue}{\psi_f(x)})$
:::

::: {class="fragment" }
- **Covariant derivative**:  
   $$D_\mu = \partial_\mu - i g A_\mu$$  
  - Couples quarks to gluons  
  - Ensures **local gauge invariance**
:::

:::

::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:0px;"}

::: {class="fragment"}
- **Gauge transformations**:  
    $\small \forall\; U(x) \in \mathrm{SU}(3)$
<div style="margin-top:-10px; margin-left:80px;">
$$
 \begin{array}{rcl}
    \psi_f & \longrightarrow & U\,\psi_f \\
    \bar{\psi}_f & \longrightarrow & \bar{\psi}_f\,U^\dagger \\
    D_\mu \psi_f & \longrightarrow & U\,D_\mu \psi_f
  \end{array}
$$
</div>
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-27px"}
- **Facts**:  
Quarks are never observed as free particles  
  - Combined into **color singlets** → hadrons
    - mesons ( $\small \pi^{\pm}, \pi^0\dots$)
    - baryons ( $\small p,n\dots$)
:::

:::

::::



## Interactions in QCD

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1"}
**Gauge invariance** not only dictates the kinetic terms, but also **fixes the interaction structure**:
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:10px; margin-left:120px; justify-content:center; font-size:1.3em; font-weight:200;"}
$\small \sim g \bar{\psi}\psi A$


:::
::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:-54px; margin-left:550px; justify-content:center; font-size:1.3em; font-weight:200;"}
$\small \sim g \partial A A A \quad \quad \quad \sim g^2 AAAA$
:::


:::{.r-hstack style="align-items:center; justify-content:center; margin-top:-10px;"}

<img src="qed-liketest-2.png" class="fragment fade-in-then-semi-out" data-fragment-index="2" style="width:20%; display:inline-block; margin-left:40px;" />
<img src="gluethree-test-2.png" class="fragment zoom-in" data-fragment-index="4" style="width:20%; display:inline-block; margin-left:240px;" />
<img src="gluefour-test-2.png" class="fragment zoom-in" data-fragment-index="4" style="width:20%; display:inline-block;" />

:::

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:-35px;"}

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2"}
- **QED-like vertex**  
  - quark–gluon interaction  
  - analogous to electron–photon in QED
:::

:::

::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:-35px;"}

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4"}
- **New in QCD**  
  - 3-gluon and 4-gluon self-interactions  
  - consequence of non-abelian $\mathrm{SU}(3)_C$  
  - lead to confinement, asymptotic freedom, glueballs...
:::

:::

::::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-10px; font-style:italic; color:gray; text-align:left;"}
  
Quantum corrections lead to divergencies:  
  Interactions are treated in the **renormalization framework** → [**running**]{style="color: #EB811B;"} of the coupling $g(\mu)$.
::: 


## Running of the Coupling

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="45%"}

::: {class="fragment"}
- **Scale dependent** coupling: $\small g \,\longrightarrow\, g(\mu)$
:::

::: {class="fragment"}
- Governed by the **β-function**:  
  $$\small
  \mu \frac{dg}{d\mu} = \beta(g),
  \quad
  \beta(g) = -\beta_0 \frac{g^3}{16\pi^2} + \mathcal{O}(g^5)
  $$
  with $\small \;\beta_0 = 11 - \tfrac{2}{3} N_f$
:::

::: {class="fragment"}
- **Solution at 1-loop**:  
  $$\small
  \alpha_s(\mu) \equiv \frac{g^2(\mu)}{4\pi}
  = \frac{1}{\beta_0 \ln(\mu^2 / \Lambda_{\text{QCD}}^2)}
  $$
:::


:::

::: {.column width="50%"}

<div style=" width: 90vw; padding-top: 66.67%;position: absolute; top:10%; left:40%; text-align: center; overflow: hidden; transform: scale(.5); transform-origin: top left;">
  <img src="axes.svg" class="fragment" style="position:absolute; top:0; left:50%; transform:translateX(-50%); width:80%; height:auto;  object-fit: contain;">
  <img src="ax_curve.svg" class="fragment" style="position:absolute; top:0; left:50%; transform:translateX(-50%); width:80%; height:auto;  object-fit: contain;">
  <img src="points_legend.svg" class="fragment zoom-in" style="position:absolute; top:1%; left:56%; transform:translateX(-50%); width:80%; height:auto; object-fit: contain; margin: auto;">
</div>

:::

::::

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}


:::


::: {.column width="50%" style="margin-top:-60px;"}

::: {class="fragment"}
- **Consequences**:  
  - $\small \mu \to \infty \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; \alpha_s(\mu) \to 0 \;\Rightarrow\; \color{#EB811B}\text{asymptotic freedom}$
  - $\small \mu \to \Lambda_{\text{QCD}} \;\;\Rightarrow\;\; \alpha_s(\mu) \to \infty \;\Rightarrow\; \color{#EB811B}\text{confinement}$  

:::

:::

::::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:10px; font-style:italic; color:gray; text-align:right;"} 
QCD becomes strongly coupled in the IR → [**non-perturbative tools**]{style="color: #EB811B;"} are required!
:::

-->
## Confinement

::: {class="fragment"}
- At low energies $\small \alpha_s(\mu) \gg 1$ 
:::

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="60%"}


::: {class="fragment"}
- **QCD potential**:
<div style="margin-top:-20px;"> 
  $$\small
  V(r) = -\,\frac{4}{3}\frac{\alpha_s}{r} + \sigma r \quad \quad \quad \;\sigma \approx 0.9\ \mathrm{GeV/fm}
  $$
</div>
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-20px;"}
- **Force**:
  <div style="margin-top:-20px;">   
  $$ \small
  |dV/dr|_{\mathrm{QCD}}  \approx 0.9 \times 1.6\cdot10^{-10} \text{J}/10^{-15}\ \text{m} 
     \approx 1.6\cdot10^{4}\ \text{N}
  $$
</div>
:::

<img src="strong-car.png" style="width:25%; margin:auto; display:block;"/>
:::


::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-40px; margin-left:25px;"}
<div style="margin-top:-20px; text-align:left;">   
$\small |dV/dr|_{\mathrm{QED}} \approx 2.3 \cdot 10^{2} \ \mathrm{N}$

## QCD at Low Energies

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column  style="margin-top:40px; width:65%;" }

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:80px;}
- For $\mu \sim \Lambda_{\text{QCD}}$:  
  - $\alpha_s(\mu)$ is large  
  - Perturbation theory breaks down
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2"}
- Physics is dominated by **non-perturbative phenomena**:  
  - Confinement  
  - Mass gap  
  - Hadron spectrum & structure
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3"}
- Need **non-perturbative tools**:
  - **Lattice QCD** (first-principles numerical approach)  
  - **Effective Field Theories** (low-energy approximations)
:::

:::

::: {.column width="35%"}
<img src="paths.png" class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="width:80%; transform: scale(1.25); margin-top:50px;"/>
:::

## Lattice QCD

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="65%"}

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:-8px;"}
- **Euclidean formulation**:  
  Discretize space-time as a **4D grid**
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top:-8px;"}
- Introduces two natural **cutoffs**:  
  - <span style="background: linear-gradient(to right, #68a0f9ff, #1e3a8a); 
               -webkit-background-clip: text; color: transparent;">
    **UV**
    </span>: lattice spacing $a$  
  - <span style="background: linear-gradient(to right, #ef8644ff, #d70d0dff); 
               -webkit-background-clip: text; color: transparent;">
    **IR**
    </span>: finite volume $L^4$
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:-8px;"}
- **Fields on the lattice**:  
  - Quarks: $\;\psi(x) \;\;\to\;\; a^{-3/2}\psi(n)$ (sites)  
  - Gauge fields: $\;A_\mu(x) \;\;\to\;\; U_\mu(n) \in \mathrm{SU}(3)$ (links)
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-8px;"}
- Gauge links act as **parallel transporters**  
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-8px;"}
- **Boundary conditions**:  
  - Periodic (PBC) for gauge fields  
  - Anti-periodic (APBC) for fermions
:::

:::

QCD becomes a set of **dimensionless variables** <br>
It can be solved numerically using **[Monte Carlo techniques]{style="color: #EB811B;"}**
:::

## Monte Carlo methods


<div style="margin-top:-20px;">
$$
\langle \mathcal{O}\rangle
= \frac{1}{Z}\int [dU]\textcolor{blue}{[d\bar\psi d\psi]}\,\mathcal{O}\, e^{-S_G[U]-\textcolor{blue}{\bar\psi} D[U]\textcolor{blue}{\psi}}
= \frac{1}{Z}\int [dU]\,\mathcal{O}_F[U]\,\textcolor{blue}{\det D[U]}\,e^{-S_G[U]}
$$
</div>




:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="70%"}

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-20px; margin-bottom:-30px;"} 
1. **Importance sampling**
Draw gauge configurations $\small \left\{ U_\mu^{(i)} \right\}$ from:
<div style="margin-top:-10px;">
$$
\mathcal{P}[U]\propto e^{-S_G[U]}\,\det D[U]
$$
</div>
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-10px;"}
2. $\small \forall i$ compute **fermionic observable**
$\langle\mathcal{O}\rangle_F[U^{(i)}]$
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-10px; margin-bottom:-20px;"}
3. Ensemble average (**estimator**)
<div style="margin-top:-10px;">
$$
\overline{\mathcal{O}} \;=\; \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N \langle\mathcal{O}\rangle_F[U^{(i)}]
\;=\; \langle\mathcal{O}\rangle \;+\; \delta\mathcal{O}
$$
</div>
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-30px;"}
4. Set the **physical scale** $\small a$ (e.g. hadron masses)
:::

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:-10px;"}

5. **Continuum / infinite-volume limits**:

<div style="margin-top:-10px;">    
  - Remove the <span style="background: linear-gradient(to right, #68a0f9ff, #1e3a8a); 
               -webkit-background-clip: text; color: transparent;">
    **UV**
    </span>($\small a \to 0$) and <span style="background: linear-gradient(to right, #ef8644ff, #d70d0dff); 
               -webkit-background-clip: text; color: transparent;">
    **IR**
    </span>($\small L \to \infty$) cut-off
  - (if needed) **chiral extrapolation** $\small m_q\to m_q^{\rm phys}$
</div>

:::


:::

::: {.column width="30%"}

<img src="markov_chain.png" class="fragment"  style="width:100%; margin-top:20px; display:block; transform: scale(1.6);"/>

::: {.fragment style="margin-top:60px;"}


| Experiments | Lattice QCD |
|------------|------------|
| Accelerators (LHC) | Ensemble of configurations |
| Detectors (CMS, ATLAS) | Fermionic observables |

:::


:::

## Why we need strong machines?

<div style="margin-top:-30px;"> 
$$
\text{Computational cost} \sim c \;\times\; (\# \text{confs}) \;\times\; 
\left(\frac{1}{M_\pi}\right)^6 \;\times\; L^5 \;\times\; (a^{-1})^7
$$
</div>

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="60%"}

::: {.fragment style="margin-top:-20px;"}

- Cost grows rapidly when approaching:
  - **physical pion masses** 
  - **large volumes** 
  - **fine lattice spacing** 

:::

::: {.fragment}
- At the **physical point** with $L=32$:  
  - Generating $3\times 10^3$ <br> → **$2\times 10^6$ core hours** configurations
  - Without parallelization on a stand-alone PC <br> → **~230 years**
:::

::: {.fragment}
- Data per configuration: $\mathcal{O}(1\text{-}50)$ GB  
  → **Tera/Petabytes of data** generated
:::

::: {.fragment}
**HPC** resources provide:   

  1. Hundreds of nodes with CPUs/GPUs 

  2. High memory per node  

  3. High network bandwidth  
 
:::

## Chiral Symmetry in QCD

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="55%"}

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1"}
- **Massless QCD Lagrangian** has  
  $\small \mathrm{SU}(N_f)_L \times \mathrm{SU}(N_f)_R$ symmetry
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2"}
- **Exact symmetry?** No!  
  → We do not observe **parity doubling**
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3"}
- Chiral symmetry is **broken**:
  - **Spontaneously**: $\langle \bar{\psi}\psi \rangle \neq 0$  
  - **Explicitly**: quark masses $m_q \neq 0$
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4"}
- Consequence: **Pseudo–Goldstone bosons**  
  → light pions emerge
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="5" style="margin-top:10px;"}
- **Gell-Mann–Oakes–Renner (GMOR) relation**:
<div style="margin-top:-15px;">
$$\small
M_\pi^2  \;=\; (m_u + m_d)\frac{\langle \bar{\psi}\psi\rangle}{f_\pi^2} 
$$
</div>
:::

:::

::: {.column width="45%"}

<img src="cool-2.png" 
     class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3"
     style="width:100%; margin-top:-30px; transform: scale(1.5)"/>


::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="6"}
**Why an EFT?**  
<div style="margin-top:-5px;">
- At **low energies**, quarks & gluons are not convenient d.o.f. 
- Relevant excitations are **pions** 
</div>
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="7" style="margin-top:10px;"}
  **How?**
<div style="margin-top:-5px;">
  - Keep underlying symmetries  
  - Expand in $p/\Lambda$ and $m_q$  
  - Emergence of **Low Energy Constants**
</div>
:::





:::

::::

## Chiral Lagrangian (LO)

<div style="text-align:center; margin-top:70px;">

$$
\mathcal{L}_\mathrm{LO} \;=\;
\frac{\textcolor{red}{f^2_\pi}}{4}\,\mathrm{Tr}\!\left[\partial_\mu U\, \partial^\mu U^\dagger\right]
\;+\;
\frac{\textcolor{red}{f^2_\pi} \textcolor{blue}{B}}{2}\,\mathrm{Tr}\!\left[M\,(U+U^\dagger)\right]
$$

</div>





:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="60%"}

::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:60px; margin-left:0px; text-align:left;"}
At LO Life is easy  
→  **two** Low-Energy Constants (LECs):

1. $\textcolor{red}{f}$ (pion decay constant)  
2. $\textcolor{blue}{B}$ (related to quark condensate)  
:::

:::


::: {.column width="40%"}



::: {class="fragment" style="margin-top:300px; text-align:center; color:gray; font-style:italic;"}
They must be fixed from **experiments** or from **Lattice QCD**
:::

:::

::::


## Chiral Lagrangian (NLO)


$$\small
\begin{aligned}
\mathcal L_{\mathrm{eff}}^{\mathrm{NLO}}=& \frac{\ell_{1}}{4}\left\{\mathrm{Tr}[D_{\mu}U(D^{\mu}U)^{\dagger}]\right\}^{2}+\frac{\ell_{2}}{4}\mathrm{Tr}[D_{\mu}U(D_{\nu}U)^{\dagger}]\mathrm{Tr}[D^{\mu}U(D^{\nu}U)^{\dagger}] 
+\frac{\ell_{3}}{16}\left[\mathrm{Tr}(\chi U^{\dagger}+U\chi^{\dagger})\right]^{2}\\&+\frac{\ell_{4}}{4}\mathrm{Tr}[D_{\mu}U(D^{\mu}\chi)^{\dagger}+D_{\mu}\chi(D^{\mu}U)^{\dagger}]+\ell_{5}\left[\mathrm{Tr}(f_{\mu\nu}^{~R}Uf_{L}^{~\mu\nu}U^{\dagger})-\frac{1}{2}\mathrm{Tr}(f_{\mu\nu}^{~L}f_{L}^{~\mu\nu}+f_{\mu\nu}^{~R}f_{R}^{~\mu\nu})\right] \\
&+i\frac{\ell_{6}}{2}\mathrm{Tr}[f_{\mu\nu}^{~R}D^{\mu}U(D^{\nu}U)^{\dagger}+f_{\mu\nu}^{~L}(D^{\mu}U)^{\dagger}D^{\nu}U]- \textcolor{SNSRed}{\color{ #EB811B}
\frac{\ell_{7}}{16}\left[\mathrm{Tr}(\chi U^{\dagger}-U\chi^{\dagger})\right]^{2}}
 +\frac{h_{1}+h_{3}}{4}\mathrm{Tr}(\chi\chi^{\dagger})\\&+\frac{h_{1}-h_{3}}{16}\left\{\left[\mathrm{Tr}(\chi U^{\dagger}+U\chi^{\dagger})\right]^{2}\right. +\left[\mathrm{Tr}(\chi U^{\dagger}-U\chi^{\dagger})\right]^{2}-2\mathrm{Tr}(\chi U^{\dagger}\chi U^{\dagger}+U\chi^{\dagger}U\chi^{\dagger})\Big\} \\
&-2h_{2}\mathrm{Tr}(f_{\mu\nu}^{~L}f_{L}^{~\mu\nu}+f_{\mu\nu}^{~R}f_{R}^{~\mu\nu})) 
\end{aligned}
$$





:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="60%"}

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top:20px; margin-left:0px; text-align:left;"}
- Emergence of new Physical effects

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:-0px; margin-left:0px; text-align:left;"}
- Among all the NLO LECs $\ell_7$ is the least known
  - **Never determined directly**
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4" style="margin-top:-0px; margin-left:0px; text-align:left;"}

# (A few) Open Problems and Challenges

## Topological Freezing



:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="45%"}

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:-10px;"}
- No trivial **topology**
- Special classical solutions of QCD  
&rightarrow; **Istantons**
- Carry an integer **topological charge $Q$**  
- Transitions between sectors  
&rightarrow; **tunneling** over energy barriers
:::

::: {class="fragment"  data-fragment-index="4" style="margin-top:-100px; margin-left:-110px; text-align:center;"}
<img src="topooo.png" style="width:70%; transform: scale(0.6)"/>
:::


:::

::: {.column width="55%"}

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top:-60px; text-align:center;"}
<img src="topo.png" style="width:100%; transform: scale(.8)"/>
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:-60px;"}
**Twofold Problem**:

1. <u>Simulation issues</u>:  
&rightarrow;  Std Alghorithms **fail** as $\small a \to 0$
2. <u>Phenomenological issues</u>:  
&rightarrow; **Thermodynamics** of the early universe  
&rightarrow; <span style="background: linear-gradient(to right, #68a0f9ff, #1e3a8a); 
               -webkit-background-clip: text; color: transparent;">
    **Cold**
    </span> and <span style="background: linear-gradient(to right, #ef8644ff, #d70d0dff); 
               -webkit-background-clip: text; color: transparent;">
    **Hot**
    </span> Axion Phenomenology  
&rightarrow; **Singlet** particle properties
:::


:::

::::

## Possible Solutions

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="60%"}

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:30px;"}
- **Parallel Tempering** 
  - Run **several copies** at different **temperatures or boundary conditions** simultaneously  
  - Swap configurations between them:  
    - 1 “physical”   
    - N “eased” replicas
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:50px;"}
- Works well in pure gauge
-  **Fermionic determinant**?  
- Requires **fine-tuning** of the tower of copies
:::

:::

## Inverse Problem/ Analytical Continuation


**Correlators** are related to **spectral function** via an **inverse Fourier transform** 

$$\small
C(t)=\int  dE\; \exp{\left[-Et\right]} \rho(E) 
$$

in **Minkowski time**


::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:10px;"}
- Simulations are performed in **Euclidean time**
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top:-10px;"}
- It means solving an **inverse Laplace problem**  
- This is **ill-posed** and **numerically unstable**
:::



:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="40%"}


:::

::: {.column width="60%"}

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4" style="margin-top:-175px;margin-left:140px;"}
$$\begin{aligned}\small
\hat \rho_\sigma(E_0) \;&=\; \int dE \; \sigma(E,E_0)\,\rho(E)\\
\small C_\sigma(t;E_0) \;&=\; \int dE \; e^{-iEt} \,\rho_\sigma(E).
\end{aligned}
$$

:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:5px;margin-left:100px;"}
- **Backus-Gilbert method**  
  - Construct smeared spectral function <!--with controlled resolution-->
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="5" style="margin-top:-15px; margin-left:100px;"}
- **Bayesian approaches** (MEM, BR, etc.)  
<!-- - Use prior knowledge to regularize the inversion -->
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="6" style="margin-top:-15px; margin-left:100px;"}
- **Other approaches**:  
  -  Neural networks, Deep-learning...
:::


:::

::::


## Application to the Sphaleron Rate

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="55%"}

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="1" style="margin-top:-10px;"}
- **Sphaleron rate** &Leftrightarrow; **frequency of topological transitions** 
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="2" style="margin-top:-10px;"}
- Measure **topological charge correlator** in Euclidean time  
$$\small C(t) = \langle Q(t) Q(0) \rangle $$
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="3" style="margin-top:-10px;"}
- Need **real-time sphaleron rate**:  
$$\small \Gamma_\mathrm{sphal} \sim \lim_{\omega\to 0} \frac{\rho(\omega)}{\omega} $$
:::


::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="4" style="margin-top:-10px;"}
- Challenges: **ill-posed**, noisy data, limited temporal extent
:::

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="5" style="margin-top:-10px;"}
- Application of **Backus-Gilbert** method
:::






:::


::: {.column width="45%"}

::: {class="fragment" data-fragment-index="6" style="margin-top:-15px; margin-left:0;"}

    // 1. Durata dell'animazione CSS (in secondi)
    const animationDuration = 20; 

    // 2. Calcola l'intervallo perfetto per ogni spotlight
    // (durata totale / numero di elementi) * 1000 per averlo in millisecondi
    const perfectInterval = (animationDuration / numUniqueItems) * 800;

    function updateSpotlight() {
      // IL CODICE CHE CAUSAVA LO STACCO È STATO RIMOSSO DA QUI

      // Rimuovi la classe 'active' da tutti gli elementi
      mainItems.forEach(el => el.classList.remove('active'));
      
      // Applica la classe 'active' all'elemento corrente e al suo duplicato
      mainItems[index].classList.add('active');
      mainItems[index + numUniqueItems].classList.add('active');
      
      // Avanza l'indice per il prossimo ciclo
      index = (index + 1) % numUniqueItems;
    }

    // 3. Avvia lo spotlight con l'intervallo calcolato e sincronizzato
    updateSpotlight();
    setInterval(updateSpotlight, perfectInterval);

    // Gestione opzionale per RevealJS (se presente)
    if (typeof Reveal !== 'undefined') {
      Reveal.on('slidechanged', event => {
        index = 0;
        updateSpotlight();
      });
    }
  });
</script>
